How we get paid

We want this to be a “win-win” situation. So we only want to get paid if we bring you value in the form of finding a personal finance option that works for you. Not by selling your data. Credible receives compensation when we help you find the best product from one of our lending partners. The amount of our compensation does not impact how and where lenders appear on our site, and Credible charges you no fees of any sort. Some lenders may take traffic sources into account when offering credit terms.

What is a private student loan?

A private student loan is an education loan issued by a bank, credit union, or online lender — not the federal government — and is one of the main student loan options you can compare when federal aid isn’t enough. These loans can help you pay for tuition, housing, textbooks, and other school-related costs when federal aid isn't enough.

If you apply for a private student loan, your eligibility and typical student loan interest rate will depend on the lender as well as your credit score, income, debt-to-income ratio, and other factors. You do have the option to apply with a student loan cosigner, which could make it easier to get approved and qualify for a low interest rate.

Private student loans vs. federal loans: What’s the difference?

Federal loans are government-backed and offer standardized student loan rates and flexible repayment options. Private education loans offer more choice and may come with lower interest rates for creditworthy borrowers, but they typically provide fewer borrower protections. Be sure you've made use of all the federal student aid you can qualify for before exploring private loans for college.

Loan type
Typical grace period
Federal Direct Subsidized and Unsubsidized Loans
6 months
Federal grad PLUS loan
No official grace period, but your in-school deferment will automatically extend for 6 months after you graduate, withdraw, or drop below half-time enrollment
Federal parent PLUS loans
No automatic grace period, but parents can request a 6-month deferment after the student graduates, withdraws, or drops below half-time enrollment
Private student loans
Varies by lender, but many offer grace periods of 6 months or longer

Who qualifies for federal and private student loans?

Eligibility for private student loans depends on several factors, including your credit score, income, and enrollment status. Most lenders require a minimum credit score (often around 670) and may also assess your income, debt-to-income ratio, and the school or program you're attending. If you have little or no credit history, applying with a cosigner can improve your chances of approval and help secure a lower student loan interest rate.

To qualify for federal student loans, basic eligibility requirements include U.S. citizenship, a valid Social Security number, enrolling at least half-time in an eligible degree or certificate program, and maintaining satisfactory academic progress. Federal loans don't require a credit check, except for PLUS loans. Financial need is considered for subsidized federal student loans, while unsubsidized loans are available to most students regardless of income.

How much can you borrow with a private student loan?

Private student loan limits vary among lenders. They usually do not exceed your school's total cost of attendance, minus any other financial aid you receive.

Federal student loan borrowing limits vary based on how far along you are in your education and whether your parents support you financially. For many students, the maximum federal student loan amounts aren't enough to cover all their education costs.

How to compare and apply for a private student loan with Credible

1. Get prequalified rates

With Credible, you can compare private student loan rates from multiple lenders at once, without hurting your credit. Simply enter your personal information, then receive an overview of your estimated rates and terms from different lenders you qualify with.

2. Compare private student loan lenders

Research each lender to compare key features and choose the right loan for you. Consider student loan rates, repayment options, fees, member benefits, and student loan reviews.

3. Select your loan

After narrowing down your list of private lenders, choose the student loan option that best suits your needs. Also consider whether you'll add a cosigner to the loan. If so, you'll need to gather some information from your cosigner to complete the next step.

4. Submit an application

Gather the necessary documentation to apply. This may include a government-issued ID, pay stubs, tax records, and more. Fill out the private loan application, provide the requested documentation, sign, and submit.

Compare private student loan lenders and current rates

Review the lenders below to compare student loan rates, repayment options, and loan terms. This can help you determine the best lender for your needs.

Expert Insights

MEFA is best for borrowers with strong credit who want stable, low-cost college financing without the extras. It offers low, fixed-interest rates and zero fees. But there are no variable rates, autopay discounts, or short-term repayment options. If you meet its credit standards, MEFA's nonprofit model makes it a reliable, no-frills alternative to traditional private lenders.

More details

Overview

Massachusetts Educational Financing Authority (MEFA) offers student loans to borrowers with good credit. However, you won't be able to see your potential rate before applying.

 

The lender doesn't charge any fees and its rates are competitive, though MEFA only offers two repayment terms. You can add a cosigner to your loan if you're unable to qualify, but only one repayment plan allows you to release your cosigner.

Eligibility

Must be a U.S. citizen or permanent resident, enrolled at least half time at a degree-granting, nonprofit institution, and must maintain satisfactory academic progress. Must have no history of default on an education loan and no history of bankruptcy or foreclosure in the past 60 months. Applicants who can’t meet the minimum credit and income requirements may apply with a cosigner.

How student loan interest works

Student loan interest is the cost of borrowing money and is typically calculated as a percentage of your outstanding loan balance, expressed as an annual percentage rate (APR).

For most federal and private student loans, interest accrues daily based on simple interest — meaning it's calculated on the original loan amount, not on previously accrued interest. Each monthly payment first covers any accrued interest, with the remainder going toward the principal. Over time, as you pay down your loan, the daily interest charges decrease. However, if you miss payments, the unpaid interest may be capitalized, or added to your principal, increasing the total loan balance and future interest charges.

Federal loans have fixed interest rates set by the government, which makes them predictable over time. Private loans may have either fixed interest rates or variable interest rates that can change based on market conditions and potentially increase your costs. Most student loans charge simple interest. In rare cases, private loans may use compound interest, which can further increase what you owe. Because interest can significantly raise your repayment costs, it's important to understand how it's calculated and explore ways to reduce it.

To minimize interest charges, consider making interest-only payments while in school, paying extra toward the principal when possible, refinancing for a lower education loan interest rate, or choosing a shorter repayment term. These strategies can help reduce the overall cost of your loan. On the flip side, ignoring interest payments — especially during school or deferment — can lead to capitalization and inflate your debt. Continued nonpayment after your loan enters repayment can lead to delinquency, default, and serious financial consequences like damaged credit and wage garnishment.

Editor insight: “To qualify for the best student loan rates, I suggest choosing one that you can pay off as quickly as you can comfortably manage. Lenders typically offer lower private student loan interest rates on shorter loan terms because there's less risk of default. You'll also repay your loan faster and reduce the total interest cost.” 

— Renee Fleck, Student Loans Editor, Credible

Student loan interest rate trends

If you’re comparing private student loans, tracking average interest rate trends can help you understand the typical student loan interest rate and find a low-interest student loan when rates dip. Interest rates are the biggest factor determining the cost of student loans. Even small differences in student loan rates can translate into thousands of dollars over the life of a loan. While federal student loan rates are the same for all borrowers, private student loan rates vary widely depending on the borrower's credit profile.

For the 2025-26 school year, federal student loan rates are fixed at 6.39% for undergraduate Direct Loans, 7.94% for graduate Direct Unsubsidized Loans, and 8.94% for PLUS Loans. Private student loan rates on the Credible platform range from 2.69% to 17.99% APR for fixed-rate loans, and from 3.66% to 17.99% APR for variable-rate loans.

Choosing between fixed and variable rates, or adjusting your repayment term, can help align borrowing costs with your long-term goals. If you're looking to minimize your total repayment amount, a lower rate can make a substantial difference — even by just 1%.

If you're considering private loans, take time to understand how interest is calculated and how your rate might change over time. Keeping track of average student loan rate trends, like those published by Credible, can help you understand the market and compare loan offers with confidence.

Pros and cons of private student loans

Private student loans can be a valuable tool for covering college costs, especially after you've maxed out scholarships, grants, and federal aid. They offer quick access to funds and may come with competitive interest rates if you or your cosigner has strong credit. However, unlike federal loans, private student loans typically lack flexible repayment options, income-based plans, and forgiveness opportunities, making it crucial to understand the pros and cons before borrowing.

Here's a quick comparison of the advantages and drawbacks of private student loans:

Pros
Cons
Can help cover the full cost of attendance
Interest starts accruing immediately (no subsidized option)
May offer lower interest rates for borrowers or cosigners with strong credit
Few borrower protections (no forgiveness, limited deferment/forbearance)
Fixed or variable interest rate options available
Risk of capitalization increasing total loan cost
Builds credit history with on-time payments
Payments may be unaffordable after graduation without flexible plans
Accessible when federal loans or aid aren’t enough
Higher default risk if you borrow more than you can repay

Before taking out a private loan, use a student loan calculator to estimate your potential monthly payments and compare them to expected earnings after graduation. Borrow only what you need, and consider making interest-only payments while in school to help manage long-term costs.

When to apply for a private student loan

The timing of your student loan applications is crucial, especially when balancing both federal and private options. Federal student loans should be your starting point, and the application process begins with completing the Free Application for Federal Student, or FAFSA. Submitting the FAFSA early improves your chances of receiving grants and other aid awarded on a first-come, first-served basis. While the FAFSA has set federal deadlines, many states and schools have their own earlier cutoff dates. Check with your state and school financial aid office to stay on track.

Private loans offer more flexibility with timing. You can apply for private student loans anytime, including during the semester. However, you should always do so as early as possible to avoid delays in processing and disbursement. Private lenders often require school certification before releasing funds. This can take several weeks. While many private lenders provide fast approval, unexpected documentation requests or school-related delays can slow the timeline, so it's best to apply well in advance of your tuition due date.

There are many student loan options available, from federal loans to private lenders. Each has different rates, repayment terms, and borrower benefits. Using Credible, you can easily compare these options side by side to find the best fit for your needs.

FAQ

How can I compare student loan interest rates?

View

To compare student loan interest rates, start by prequalifying with multiple lenders. You’ll see personalized rate estimates without affecting your credit score. Then, review APRs, repayment terms, and borrower benefits to understand which loan options may cost less over time.

Which student loan should I accept?

View

Start with federal student loans, which offer fixed rates, income-driven repayment options, and no credit requirements. If you still need additional funding, explore private student loans and compare interest rates, repayment terms, and borrower features.

What student loan rates are available in 2026?

View

Student loan rates currently available through the Credible platform for qualified borrowers include fixed APRs starting at 2.69% and variable-rate APRs from 3.66%.

How much do student loans for college cost per month?

View

Your monthly student loan payment depends on your loan amount, interest rate, and repayment term. Loans with lower interest rates and smaller balances typically cost less each month. A longer repayment term lowers your payment but increases total interest, while a shorter term raises your payment but helps you save overall.

How do I compare private student loan interest rates?

View

Use a platform like Credible to compare private student loan interest rates, make a student loans comparison, consider insights from student loans reviews, and find low-interest options from top lenders without affecting your credit. Look at both fixed and variable APRs, as well as repayment terms and borrower perks.

What affects current private student loan interest rates?

View

Your student loan rates are determined by several factors, including credit score, income, debt-to-income ratio, and whether you apply with a cosigner. Lenders also consider your school or program, and whether you choose fixed-rate college loans or variable-rate options.

Can I get a private student loan with bad credit or no credit?

View

You can get a student loan with bad credit from a private lender, but it's difficult. Lenders usually require good credit, with most looking for a credit score of 670 or better. Applying with a cosigner who has strong credit can improve your chances of approval and help you get a better rate.

Do I need a cosigner for a private student loan?

View

You don't always need a cosigner for a private student loan. But if you have limited or bad credit, a cosigner may be required. A creditworthy cosigner can help you get approved for a student loan and may qualify you for a lower student loan interest rate than you'd get on your own.

How do I compare private student loan options?

View

Compare lenders by looking at interest rates (fixed vs. variable), repayment terms, fees, borrower protections, and student loan reviews. Using a tool like Credible lets you view multiple prequalified offers at once without affecting your credit score.

What credit score do I need to get a private student loan?

View

Most private student loan providers look for a credit score of at least 670. The higher your credit score, the lower your interest rate is likely to be. If you have a limited credit history, or none at all, applying for a student loan with a creditworthy cosigner can boost your chances of approval and help secure better terms.

Can I use private student loans for non-tuition expenses?

View

You can use private student loans for more than just tuition. As long as the total amount doesn't exceed your school's certified cost of attendance, you can use the funds for books, supplies, housing, meals, transportation, and other education-related expenses.

Is it possible to refinance private student loans later?

View

Many borrowers refinance student loans after graduation to qualify for a lower interest rate, better repayment terms, or both, especially if their credit or income has improved. Refinancing student loans may also allow you to combine multiple loans into one. Just be aware that refinancing federal loans into a private loan eliminates federal protections like income-driven repayment or loan forgiveness.

What is private student loan debt?

View

Private student loan debt is money borrowed from a non-government lender to pay for college. Unlike federal student loans, approval and interest rates for most private loans depend on your credit, and these loans come with fewer borrower protections.

How do you calculate monthly interest on loans for students?

View

Most student loans are simple interest loans. To calculate your monthly interest on a simple interest loan, multiply your current loan balance by your annual interest rate, then divide by 12. For a quicker estimate, you can also use Credible's student loan calculator to model your monthly payments.

How much is a student loan?

View

The cost of a student loan depends on factors including the amount borrowed, interest rate, and repayment term — all factors you can review when you compare student loans. Lower rates and smaller balances generally mean more affordable monthly payments. Choosing a longer repayment term can reduce your monthly bill but increase your total interest paid, while a shorter term raises your monthly payments but lowers your overall interest cost.

Methodology

To determine the best student loan lenders, Credible collected more than 1,000 points of data on two dozen companies and evaluated them on several different categories: repayment options, eligibility, interest rates, loan terms, and customer support. We assigned a score out of five stars to each lender based on our findings. Below are the weightings assigned to the general categories for the best student loan companies — which comprise individual criteria that are also weighted.

  • Repayment options: 30%
  • Eligibility: 25%
  • Interest rates: 20%
  • Loan terms: 15%
  • Customer support: 10%

While the best lender for you will depend on your unique needs and financial circumstances, these findings should help answer your questions and assist you in your search for the best student loan.
